G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and the applicable jurisdictional provisions governing civil actions in the District Court Department, because the damages claimed are within the monetary jurisdiction of the Lynn Division of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 & 2, because the cause of action arose in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts, and the Property owned, managed, and/or controlled by Defendant is located at 150 Maple Street, Lynn, Massachusetts 01905, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant, as landlord and owner/manager of the Building, owed all tenants, including Plaintiff, a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the common areas of the Building, including common hallways and life-safety systems, in a reasonably safe condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring opinion in Mounsey and addresses the general abolition of the licensee/invitee distinction and the treatment of trespassers; it does not discuss landlord-tenant duties or common areas of a residential building. While Mounsey more broadly concerns occupiers’ duties to entrants, this specific text does not establish that a landlord owes tenants a duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas and life-safety systems, so it does not clearly support the detailed proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.proposition: This duty extends to the maintenance of building safety systems, including smoke detectors and other fire safety equipment, where such systems are under the landlord’s control and are intended for the protection of tenants.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion does expand a landlord’s common-law duty, holding that landlords owe a general duty of reasonable care to maintain rented premises in a safe condition, not just common areas. However, the case deals with a defective porch railing and does not specifically address building safety systems, smoke detectors, or fire safety equipment. While its general negligence principle could be extended to such systems, the decision itself does not explicitly establish a duty particular to fire safety equipment under the landlord’s control, so it does not directly support the proposition as stated.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 167\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk… Our statutes do not support limiting a landlord’s negligence liability to areas under his control… Thus, the landlord is liable in negligence for defects of which he has notice, even though the defect occurs on the rented premises.”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.proposition: A landlord must exercise reasonable care to inspect and repair dangerous conditions in common areas that the landlord knows about or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should know about.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas under the landlord’s control to all lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests. While the opinion focuses on statutory lighting and general maintenance rather than using the exact words "inspect and repair," the duty of reasonable care necessarily encompasses taking reasonable steps to discover and remedy dangerous conditions the landlord knows or should know about. Thus, the case supports the proposition at the level of general duty, even if it does not separately spell out the knowledge component.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82 (19.relevant_excerpt: In summary, we hold that Massios owed Lindsey a duty to use reasonable care in the maintenance of the premises on which Lindsey was injured. If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider... The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants.

Falden v. Gordon, 333 Mass. 135, 137 (19.proposition: A landlord who has actual or constructive notice of a defect in a common area has a duty to repair that defect within a reasonable time and may be held liable for injuries proximately caused by the failure to do so.
Falden v. Gordon, 333 Mass. 135, 137 (19.support_reasoning: The case is decided on a contractual undertaking by the landlord to clear snow and ice, not on any general common‑law duty arising from actual or constructive notice of a defect in a common area. The court assumes arguendo that a duty could arise from the agreement and then holds for the landlord because there was no evidence that the hazardous condition existed long enough that he should have discovered and remedied it. It does not articulate or apply a general rule about a landlord’s notice-based duty to repair defects in common areas absent such an express agreement.
Falden v. Gordon, 333 Mass. 135, 137 (19.relevant_excerpt: And the defendant would be liable on this second count only for negligent failure to perform this undertaking. ... Upon careful consideration of the evidence we are of opinion that it was not shown that the ice on which the plaintiff claims she slipped came from dripping icicles which the plaintiff testified she had previously seen rather than from recent snow or freezing rain and drizzle, and that it was not shown that the condition of which she complains had existed long enough before the accident so that in the exercise of proper care the defendant ought to have discovered and remedied it.

Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.proposition: A landlord who has actual or constructive notice of a defect in a common area has a duty to repair that defect within a reasonable time and may be held liable for injuries proximately caused by the failure to do so.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses two distinct regimes: (1) common areas or other areas in the landlord’s control, governed by a general duty of reasonable care without limiting language about notice and opportunity to repair; and (2) G.L. c. 186, § 19, which imposes a notice-and-reasonable-time-to-repair requirement, but expressly carves out owner‑occupied two‑ or three‑family dwellings like the building in this case. The Crowell court therefore does not set out the specific rule that a landlord with actual or constructive notice of a common‑area defect has a duty to repair it within a reasonable time; instead, it applies a broader negligence standard for areas under the landlord’s control and mentions § 19 only as background policy. The proposition is thus not accurately supported by this case.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.relevant_excerpt: “If the landlord retained control of the porch, he was under a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep it in such condition that others would not be injured. Under King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, if a breach of that duty caused injury to a tenant, it made no difference whether the porch was a common area, whether the defect existed at the time of the letting of the property, or whether the defect was a violation of the building code of the city. Cf. G. L. c. 186, § 15E … which is more limited in scope.”

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26F.proposition: As owner and landlord of the Building, Defendant was required by G.L. c. 148, § 26F, and applicable fire and building codes to install and maintain operable smoke detectors in the common areas of the Building, including the third-floor hallway outside Plaintiff’s apartment.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 3T.proposition: G.L. c. 143, §§ 3, 3T, and related provisions (governing building safety and enforcement of building codes);

780 CMR.proposition: The State Building Code, 780 CMR, including provisions adopting NFPA 72 (National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code) and requiring the installation and maintenance of smoke detection systems in multi-unit residential occupancies;

NFPA 72 (National Fire Alarm and Signali.raw_text: NFPA 72 (National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code)
NFPA 72 (National Fire Alarm and Signali.proposition: The State Building Code, 780 CMR, including provisions adopting NFPA 72 (National Fire Alarm and Signaling Code) and requiring the installation and maintenance of smoke detection systems in multi-unit residential occupancies;

527 CMR.proposition: The State Fire Code, 527 CMR and 527 CMR 1.00, including provisions requiring maintenance of fire protection and detection systems in an operable condition.

527 CMR 1.00.proposition: The State Fire Code, 527 CMR and 527 CMR 1.00, including provisions requiring maintenance of fire protection and detection systems in an operable condition.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: While a violation of a statute, regulation, or building/fire code is not per se negligence, such violations may constitute evidence of negligence and of the standard of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of statutory violations on negligence under Massachusetts law. It expressly states that violation of a statute does not constitute negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence and references earlier cases applying that rule. That matches the proposition that code/statutory violations are not per se negligence but may be evidence of negligence and of the standard of reasonable care.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.raw_text: LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979)
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.proposition: While a violation of a statute, regulation, or building/fire code is not per se negligence, such violations may constitute evidence of negligence and of the standard of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.case_name: LaClair v. Silberline Manufacturing Co., Inc.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute (and similar enactments) is not conclusive of civil liability, but is evidence of negligence as to the harms the statute was meant to prevent. Although the discussion is in the context of the workers’ compensation statute rather than building or fire codes, the court speaks in general terms about ‘a safety statute or like enactment,’ which encompasses regulations and codes as part of the standard of reasonable care.
LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “As has been frequently stated, a violation of a safety statute or like enactment, while not conclusive on the ultimate issue of civil liability, is evidence of a violator’s negligence as to all consequences that the statute was intended to prevent. Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836, 841 (1976). Underlying this rule is the general belief that the duties imposed by legislatively-prescribed conduct are normally reasonable ones to bear.”

King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.raw_text: King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 662–63 (1977)
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, where a landlord retains control over a building system or common area for the benefit and safety of tenants, the landlord is liable if it fails to act with reasonable care in maintaining that system and such failure causes foreseeable injury.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: The court explicitly adopts the Restatement (Second) of Property § 17.3 rule that a landlord who retains control over common areas used by tenants owes a continuing duty of reasonable care in maintaining those areas, and is liable for injuries caused by dangerous conditions that the landlord could have discovered and made safe. The opinion applies that rule to a common stairway retained in the landlord’s control and used for the safety and benefit of tenants, holding the landlord to a general duty of reasonable care, which aligns with the proposition stated.
King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… The landlord should not be allowed to remain in such a position that he has no incentive to maintain the areas retained under his control in reasonably safe condition… Section 17.3 reads as follows: ‘A landlord who leases a part of his property and retains in his own control any other part the tenant is entitled to use… is subject to liability… if the landlord by the exercise of reasonable care could have… discovered the condition… and… made the condition safe.’”

Piekos v. Bachand, 333 Mass. 211, 213\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, where a landlord retains control over a building system or common area for the benefit and safety of tenants, the landlord is liable if it fails to act with reasonable care in maintaining that system and such failure causes foreseeable injury.
Piekos v. Bachand, 333 Mass. 211, 213\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract case about the sale of Christmas trees and whether the seller was operating a prohibited ‘nursery’ without proper certification under Massachusetts agricultural statutes. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, retained control of building systems or common areas, negligence standards, or foreseeability of injury. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition concerning landlord liability for failure to maintain building systems or common areas.
Piekos v. Bachand, 333 Mass. 211, 213\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The judge ruled that the plaintiff was not conducting a nursery and the sale was not in violation of law. These rulings of the judge present the only questions before us. The accuracy of these rulings depends in large measure upon the correctness of the findings of fact by the judge. We are of opinion that the findings of the judge were warranted by the evidence.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient under Massachusetts law that Defendant’s conduct was a substantial contributing factor in producing Plaintiff’s injuries.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is from a concurrence and addresses foreseeability and the court’s treatment of earlier ‘keys left in ignition’ cases, not the standard of causation or whether negligence must be the sole cause. It does not articulate or endorse the ‘substantial contributing factor’ standard described in the proposition. Without further text from the majority opinion, this excerpt cannot be relied on as authority for that causation rule.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “The court unnecessarily reaches out and declares that our cases involving keys left in ignitions are ‘no longer persuasive,’ ante at 640, because these decisions are inconsistent with our expanded concept of causation. I cannot join this conclusion.… I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient under Massachusetts law that Defendant’s conduct was a substantial contributing factor in producing Plaintiff’s injuries.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent focused on lack of proof of proximate cause, not on the standard that negligence need not be the sole cause so long as it is a substantial contributing factor. Nowhere does the dissent articulate or apply a “substantial contributing factor” test, nor does it discuss whether multiple causes can combine to produce injury. Thus, this portion of Mullins v. Pine Manor College does not provide authority for the claimed Massachusetts causation proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff testified that en route from the dormitory to the refectory, she and the assailant proceeded underneath the chains of a courtyard gate which was not adequately secured, and that the door to the refectory, where the rape occurred, was unlocked. Even if the rape would not have occurred but for those conditions, the jury was unwarranted in finding that those conditions proximately caused her injury.

Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.raw_text: Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mass. 91, 107 (2009)
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all injuries proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including past and future medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and non-economic damages such as pain and suffering and emotional distress.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.support_reasoning: The case is a G.L. c. 151B gender discrimination and punitive damages decision, not a negligence or general tort damages case. While it discusses categories of damages such as back pay, front pay, and emotional distress within the statutory discrimination framework, it does not articulate a general Massachusetts rule that a negligence plaintiff is entitled to full and fair compensation for all proximately caused injuries including medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and pain and suffering. Therefore it does not support the broad tort-damages proposition asserted.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The jury awarded $17,700 in special damages, $125,000 in emotional distress damages, back pay of $95,000, and front pay of $733,307. See Stonehill College v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 549, 567-568, cert. denied sub nom. Wilfert Bros. Realty Co. v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 543 U.S. 979 (2004) (to effectuate remedial purpose of statute, compensatory damages include those which are “natural and probable consequences” of discriminatory act).

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all injuries proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including past and future medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and non-economic damages such as pain and suffering and emotional distress.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability, duty to warn, design defect, consortium, limitations, evidentiary issues, and excessiveness of the verdict, but it does not articulate any general rule about the categories of recoverable damages under Massachusetts negligence law. The only damages discussion concerns whether a $440,000 personal‑injury verdict (for serious hand injuries) was excessive, not a statement that plaintiffs are entitled to recover all past and future medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and non‑economic damages. Thus it does not serve as authority for the broad compensatory‑damages proposition stated.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any such negligence would be less than that of Defendant and would only proportionally reduce, but not bar, her recovery.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and other applicable law;
